titleText.ttltext: Burden of Human papillomavirus (HPV)-related disease and potential impact of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in the Republic of Korea

organizations: Unit of Infections and Cancer, Cancer Epidemiology Research Programme, Institut Català d′Oncologia—Catalan Institute of Oncology

paras: Background: We aimed to review the burden and the potential impact of human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccines@hit_end on HPV-related diseases in the Republic of Korea and to discuss cervical cancer prevention practices in this country. Methods: Cancer burden statistics were retrieved from GLOBOCAN-2018 and Statistics Korea. HPV disease burden was assessed via @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end types relative contribution (RC) was estimated using data from an international project using formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded specimens. Results: Despite a downtrend in cervical cancer in recent years, Korean rates remain high. In contrast, oropharyngeal cancer incidence has gradually increased and other anogenital cancers remain rare. In Korea, HPV prevalence in general population is around 20%. In cervical cancer, RC of HPVs 16/18 (74.0%) increased to 92.0% when including HPVs 31/33/45/52/58. Limited information was available for other HPV-related cancer sites. Regarding prevention, since the inclusion of the HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end into the National @hit_startImmunization@hit_end Program, almost half (49%) of the target cohort in 2016 had received the first dose of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. Further, percentage of women screened with pap has increased from 41.1%-2009 to 53.0%-2016. Conclusions: HPV-related disease burden in Korea is significant. Results suggest that the combination of effective and high coverage HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and screening programmes could substantially impact on HPV-related disease in Korea.

titleText.ttltext: Rapid diagnostic tests for determining dengue serostatus: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and key informant interviews

organizations: International Diagnostics Centre, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

paras: Objectives: @hit_startVaccination@hit_end for dengue with the live attenuated tetravalent CYD-TDV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (Dengvaxia®)is only recommended in individuals who have had prior dengue virus (DENV)infection. Rapid diagnostic tests (RDT)for past DENV infection would offer a convenient method for pre-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end screening at point-of-care. A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was conducted to evaluate the performance of current dengue RDTs for determining dengue serostatus, using IgG antibodies against DENV as a marker of past infection. Methods: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end databases were searched from 2000 to 2018 to identify studies evaluating dengue RDTs in individuals with known or possible previous DENV infection. Study quality was evaluated using GRADE and QUADAS-2 criteria. Semi-structured interviews were also performed with available dengue RDT manufacturers. Results: The performance of four dengue IgG RDTs was determined in 3137 individuals across ten studies conducted in 13 countries, with serum used in most of the studies. No studies reported data for determining dengue serostatus, and limited data were available regarding cross-reactivity with other viruses. The majority of studies demonstrated sensitivities and specificities between 80% and 100% for dengue IgG detection in samples from secondary infection or convalescent time-points after recent infection. Conclusions: Although current dengue IgG RDTs have shown reasonable performance compared with laboratory-based tests in secondary infection, additional research is needed to determine how RDTs would perform in relevant populations targeted for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. New RDTs or modifications to current RDTs are feasible and may optimize the performance of these tests for use in a pre-@hit_startvaccination@hit_end screening approach.

titleText.ttltext: Disparities and reverse disparities in HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Health Policy and Management, Gillings School of Global Public Health, University of North Carolina

paras: Studies disagree about whether racial and ethnic groups have lower or higher human papillomavirus (HPV) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end uptake, an important issue given large disparities in some HPV cancers. We sought to characterize and explain racial and ethnic differences in HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. We systematically searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and Web of Science to identify US studies through mid-2017 reporting associations of race and ethnicity with HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. We identified 118 studies (n = 3,095,486) published in English that reported HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end initiation or follow-through in the US from which we could calculate effect sizes. We used random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to synthesize effect sizes for comparisons of Whites or non-Hispanics to Blacks, Hispanics, Asians, or all minority groups combined. Studies showed no racial or ethnic differences in HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end initiation overall. However, when restricting to studies using provider-verified @hit_startvaccination@hit_end data, minorities were 6.1% [3.3%–8.8%] more likely than Whites to initiate HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Advantages were larger for Hispanics, males, and younger samples (age < 18). In contrast, minorities were 8.6% [5.6%, 11.7%], less likely than Whites to follow-through with the full HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end series, a disparity present across all participant and study characteristics. More recent studies found larger advantages for racial and ethnic minorities in HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end initiation and smaller disparities in follow-through. In summary, high-quality studies found racial and ethnic minorities are more likely to initiate but less likely to follow-through with HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, a clear finding that self-report studies obscure. Higher HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end initiation among minorities suggests potential reductions in HPV cancer disparities.

titleText.ttltext: Molecular epidemiology of human papillomaviruses from cervical samples in Ethiopia: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

paras: Background-aim: Over 99% of cervical cancer cases are associated with infections of Human papillomaviruses (HPVs). In order to draw up optimal @hit_startvaccination@hit_end strategies and HPV based cervical cancer screening, collected data on the genotype distribution of HPVs is crucial that is otherwise missed in Ethiopia. Therefore, the aim of this study was to review and compile the results of studies conducted on HPV genotyping in Ethiopia. Methods: Published articles were systematically searched starting from conception to 27 July 2018 using comprehensive search strings from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end/@hit_startMedline@hit_end and SCOPUS. Besides, other databases like Google Scholar and the Google databases were also searched manually for grey literature. Two of the authors of this review independently appraised the studies for scientific quality and extracted the data using the Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI)tools. The pooled HPV genotype distribution was presented with descriptive statistics and summary measures. Results: The included studies were undertaken in three different areas of the country (Central, Southwest and South)between 2010 and 2014. Some 859 women (age range 15–85 years)with different kinds of cervical abnormalities were included, from whom a total of 534 HPV sequences were reported. Of the reported genotypes, the proportion of HR-HPVs was at 80.4 to100%. The top five genotypes were HPV 16 (45.3%; 95%CI: 41.1–49.6%), HPV 52 (9.4%; 95%CI: 7.2–12.1%), HPV 18 (8.2%; 95%CI: 6.2–10.9%), HPV 58 (6.9%; 95%CI: 5.1–9.4%)and HPV 45 (5.2%: 95%CI: 3.7–7.5%). The combined prevalence of HPV 16/18 was at 53.6% (95%CI: 49.3–57.8%). Some other reported high risk HPV groups were HPV 31 (3.9%), HPV 33 (2.8%), HPV 39 (2.4%), HPV 51(1.1%), HPV 56 (3.7%)and HPV 68 (2.4%). HPV 6 at 2.8% (95%CI: 1.7–4.9%)was the predominant low risk type. Conclusions: In this review, HPV 16 in particular, but also HPV 52 and 18, warrant exceptional consideration in @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and HPV based cervical screening programs in Ethiopia. To the best of our knowledge, this review represents the first of its kind to establish the genotype distribution of HPV from different kinds of cervical lesions in Ethiopia although it is synthesized out of very few studies. Hence, additional nationwide data are needed to strengthen our finding.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startImmunization@hit_end and multiple sclerosis: Recommendations from the French Multiple Sclerosis Society

organizations: Service de neurologie, sclérose en plaques, pathologies de la myéline et neuro-inflammation–hôpital neurologique Pierre-Wertheimer

paras: Objectives: To establish recommendations on @hit_startimmunization@hit_end for patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). Background: @hit_startVaccines@hit_end have been suspected in the past to trigger MS and relapses. With the extension of the immunoactive treatment arsenal, other concerns have been raised more recently about an increased risk of infection or a decreased effectiveness of @hit_startimmunization@hit_end in immunosuppressed patients. Methods: The French Group for Recommendations into Multiple Sclerosis (France4MS) performed a systematic search of papers in @hit_startMedline@hit_end and other university databases (January 1975–June 2018). The RAND/UCLA appropriateness method was chosen to @hit_startreview@hit_end the scientific @hit_startliterature@hit_end and to formalize the degree of agreement among experts on 5 clinical questions related to @hit_startimmunization@hit_end and MS. Readers from the steering committee conducted a systematic @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, wrote a critical synthesis and prepared a list of proposals that were evaluated by a rating group of 28 MS experts. The final version of the recommendations was finally reviewed by a reading group of 110 health care professionals and classified as appropriate, inappropriate or uncertain. Results: Neurologists should verify the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status as soon as MS is diagnosed and before disease-modifying treatments (DMTs) are introduced. The French @hit_startvaccination@hit_end schedule applies to MS patients and seasonal influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is recommended. In the case of treatment-induced immunosuppression, MS patients should be informed about the risk of infection and the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end standards of the French High Council of Health should be applied. Live attenuated @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are contra-indicated in patients recently treated with immunosuppressive drugs, including corticosteroids; other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end can be proposed whatever the treatment, but their effectiveness may be partly reduced with some drugs. Conclusion: Physicians and patients should be aware of the updated recommendations for immunizations of patients with MS.

paras: Infectious diarrhoea remains a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Viruses, bacteria and protozoa are responsible for most infections, which are most commonly transmitted by the faecal–oral route through water, food and person-to-person transmission. Clinical presentation of infectious diarrhoea conforms to three patterns: acute watery diarrhoea; bloody diarrhoea (dysentery); and persistent diarrhoea, which can include steatorrhoea. Diagnosis still rests heavily on stool microscopy and culture, although faecal antigen tests and molecular assays are increasingly used. Oral rehydration therapy continues to be the most important supportive intervention, particularly in acute watery diarrhoea, in which death from dehydration and acidosis can be prevented in the vast majority of cases. There have been some important advances in the development of new approaches to antibiotic therapy. The non-absorbable antibiotic rifaximin is highly effective in the treatment of travellers' diarrhoea and has fewer adverse effects than systemically absorbed antibiotics. The broad-spectrum antimicrobial nitazoxanide is often effective in the treatment of cryptosporidiosis but is also effective in giardiasis, amoebiasis and Clostridium difficile infection. Recent @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end suggest that promicrobial therapies, including faecal microbial transplantation, have a place in the prophylaxis and treatment of antibiotic-associated diarrhoea, especially C. difficile infection, and acute diarrhoea in children.

titleText.ttltext: Interventions to increase uptake of the human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in unvaccinated college students: A @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end

organizations: The University of Mississippi, Department of Pharmacy Administration

paras: Objective: The purpose of this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end is to summarize the best available evidence on interventions that could be implemented in the college environment to increase HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end uptake in college students who were not previously @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end. Methods: @hit_startPubmed@hit_end, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end, and EBSCO were searched in December 2017 to identify all literature meeting the following criteria: human subjects, English language, HPV, HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, and college. PRISMA recommendations were followed. We focused only on manuscripts that reported @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake, excluding studies that only reported @hit_startvaccine@hit_end intentions. We identified 2989 articles; 101 relevant after screening; nine eligible for final qualitative review. Results: @hit_startVaccine@hit_end uptake rates ranged from 5% to 53%. Theory-based variables (e.g., perceived susceptibility and self-efficacy)were associated with @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake in most studies. A study exposing participants to a narrative video about HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end led by a combination of peers and medical experts produced the greatest difference in HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end initiation compared to a control group (21.8% vs 11.8%)of all the studies reviewed. Conclusions: Few interventions resulted in substantial HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake. A combination of peer and provider encouragement may be the most effective method to increase @hit_startvaccine@hit_end uptake in this population.

organizations: Hospices Civils de Lyon, Service de Neurologie, sclérose en plaques, pathologies de la myéline et neuro-inflammation

paras: Objectives: To establish recommendations on @hit_startimmunization@hit_end for patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) Background: @hit_startVaccines@hit_end have been suspected in the past to trigger MS and relapses. With the extension of the immunoactive treatment arsenal, other concerns have been raised more recently about an increased risk of infection or a decreased effectiveness of @hit_startimmunization@hit_end in immunosuppressed patients. Methods: The French Group for Recommendations into Multiple Sclerosis (France4MS) performed a systematic search of papers in @hit_startMedline@hit_end and other university databases (January 1975-June 2018). The RAND/UCLA appropriateness method was chosen to @hit_startreview@hit_end the scientific @hit_startliterature@hit_end and to formalize the degree of agreement among experts on 5 clinical questions related to @hit_startimmunization@hit_end and MS. Readers from the steering committee conducted a systematic @hit_startanalysis@hit_end, wrote a critical synthesis and prepared a list of proposals that were evaluated by a rating group of 28 MS experts. The final version of the recommendations was finally reviewed by a reading group of 110 health care professionals and classified as appropriate, inappropriate or uncertain. Results: Neurologists should verify the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end status as soon as MS is diagnosed and before disease-modifying treatments (DMTs) are introduced. The French @hit_startvaccination@hit_end schedule applies to MS patients and seasonal influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end is recommended. In the case of treatment-induced immunosuppression, MS patients should be informed about the risk of infection and the @hit_startvaccination@hit_end standards of the French High Council of Health should be applied. Live attenuated @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are contra-indicated in patients recently treated with immunosuppressive drugs, including corticosteroids; other @hit_startvaccines@hit_end can be proposed whatever the treatment, but their effectiveness may be partly reduced with some drugs. Conclusion: Physicians and patients should be aware of the updated recommendations for immunizations of patients with MS.

titleText.ttltext: One-way SMS and healthcare outcomes in Africa: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end of randomised trials with @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Clinical Research, University of Southern Denmark

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 Linde et al. This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original author and source are credited.
paras: Background The impact of one-way SMS on health outcomes in Africa is unclear. We aimed to conduct a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of one-way SMS randomised trials in Africa and a @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of their effect on healthcare appointments attendance and medicine adherence. Methods @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, CENTRAL, The Global Health Library, ClinicalTrials.gov, ICTRP, and PACTR were searched for published and unpublished trials in Africa without language restriction (up to April 2018). Trials reporting effect estimates on healthcare appointment attendance and medicine adherence were assessed for risk of bias and included in @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end using random-effects models. Other outcomes were reported descriptively. The protocol is registered in PROSPERO, ID:CRD42018081062. Results We included 38 one-way SMS trials conducted in Africa within a broad range of clinical conditions. Eighteen trials were included in the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end, and four were assessed as overall low risk of bias. One-way SMS improved appointment attendance, OR:203; 95% CI:140–295 (12 trials, 6448 participants), but not medicine adherence, RR:110; 95% CI:098–123 (nine trials, 4213 participants). Subgroup @hit_startanalyses@hit_end showed that one-way SMS had the highest impact on childhood @hit_startimmunization@hit_end attendance, OR:369; 95% CI:167–813 (three trials, 1943 participants). There was no clear evidence of one-way SMS improving facility delivery, knowledge level (reproductive/antenatal health, hypertension), diabetes- and hypertension management. Conclusion In an African setting, the clinical effect of one-way SMS is uncertain except for appointment attendance where the effect seems to vary depending on which clinical condition it is used in.
